parts:
show! estamos quase l√°. Dois ajustes finais pra ficar redondo:

1) aquele aviso ‚ÄúMissing character ‚Ä¶ U+2011‚Äù √© o h√≠fen ‚Äúinquebr√°vel‚Äù (non‚Äëbreaking hyphen). Vamos trocar por h√≠fen normal antes de gerar.
2) teu ‚Äúbloco de metadados‚Äù ainda est√° vazando para o corpo (linhas tipo `instituicao: ‚Ä¶`). Vamos remover qualquer bloco `chave: valor` no in√≠cio dos `.md` e tamb√©m a se√ß√£o ‚ÄúSugest√µes de linkagem‚Äù.

Abaixo vai um script √∫nico, 100% via `cat`, que cria/atualiza o cabe√ßalho ABNT e a capa, saneia os `.md`, remove o que n√£o deve e gera o PDF. Pode colar tudo no terminal:

```bash
# ===== 1) Script completo =====
cat > "$HOME/relatorio_cap1_min.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# --- entradas (ajuste se mudar de lugar) ---
INTRO="/Users/marcosmenezes/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Pessoal/USP/Projeto_ICB_Consci√™ncia/ICB-USP_Consci√™ncia/01_The_Character_of_Consciousness/intro.md"
CAP1="/Users/marcosmenezes/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Pessoal/USP/Projeto_ICB_Consci√™ncia/ICB-USP_Consci√™ncia/01_The_Character_of_Consciousness/Cap√≠tulo_01_Facing_Up_to_the_Problem_of_Consciousness/Conceitos_Chave.md"
OUT="$HOME/Relatorio_Cap1.pdf"

TITLE="Relat√≥rio de Leitura ‚Äî The Character of Consciousness (Cap√≠tulo 1)"
AUTHOR="Marcos Antonio de Menezes"
ADVISOR="Prof. Walter Chesnut"
INSTIT="Universidade de S√£o Paulo ‚Äî Instituto de Ci√™ncias Biom√©dicas (ICB‚ÄëUSP)"
CITY="S√£o Paulo"
DATE="$(date +%d/%m/%Y)"

# --- 2) Cabe√ßalho ABNT (sempre regrava, pra garantir consist√™ncia) ---
cat > "$HOME/abnt_header.tex" <<'TEX'
\usepackage[brazil]{babel}
\usepackage{fontspec}
\setmainfont{Times New Roman}
\usepackage[a4paper,top=3cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=2cm]{geometry}
\usepackage{setspace}\onehalfspacing
\usepackage{indentfirst}
\setlength{\parindent}{1.25cm}
\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}
\providecommand{\tightlist}{\setlength{\itemsep}{0pt}\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}}
\renewcommand{\labelitemi}{\textbullet}
\usepackage[hidelinks]{hyperref}
\usepackage{fancyhdr}
\pagestyle{fancy}\fancyhf{}\fancyfoot[C]{\thepage}
% Garante "Sum√°rio" em PT-BR mesmo com article
\addto\captionsbrazil{\renewcommand{\contentsname}{Sum√°rio}}
TEX

# --- 3) Capa (titlepage) ---
cat > "$HOME/abnt_cover.tex" <<TEX
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{center}
  {\Large \textbf{$TITLE}}\par
  \vspace{1.2cm}
  {$AUTHOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {Orientador: $ADVISOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {$INSTIT}\par
  \vfill
  {$CITY}\par
  {$DATE}\par
\end{center}
\clearpage
TEX

# --- 4) Sanitiza√ß√£o m√≠nima e filtros nos .md (trabalha em c√≥pias tempor√°rias) ---
TMP_INTRO="$(mktemp /tmp/intro_XXXXXX.md)"
TMP_CAP1="$(mktemp /tmp/cap1_XXXXXX.md)"
cp -f "$INTRO" "$TMP_INTRO"
cp -f "$CAP1"  "$TMP_CAP1"

# 4.1 normaliza quebras, remove controles, VS16 e emojis + troca h√≠fen inquebr√°vel (U+2011) por '-'
perl -CS -Mutf8 -i -pe '
  s/\r\n?/\n/g;
  s/[\x00-\x08\x0B\x0C\x0E-\x1F\x7F]//g;     # C0 + DEL
  s/[\x{80}-\x{9F}]//g;                      # C1
  s/\x{FE0F}//g;                             # VS16
  s/[\x{1F000}-\x{1FAFF}\x{1F300}-\x{1F6FF}\x{1F900}-\x{1F9FF}\x{2600}-\x{26FF}]//g;  # emojis/s√≠mbolos
  s/\x{2011}/-/g;                            # non-breaking hyphen -> hyphen
' "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1"

# 4.2 remove bloco YAML inicial (--- ... ---) e "chave: valor" soltos no in√≠cio
awk '
  BEGIN{in_yaml=0; started=0}
  NR==1 && /^\-\-\-$/ {in_yaml=1; next}
  in_yaml { if (/^\-\-\-$/){in_yaml=0; next} else next }
  !started && /^[A-Za-z_][-A-Za-z_0-9]*:[[:space:]]/ {next}
  {started=1; print}
' "$TMP_INTRO" > "$TMP_INTRO.clean" && mv "$TMP_INTRO.clean" "$TMP_INTRO"
awk '
  BEGIN{in_yaml=0; started=0}
  NR==1 && /^\-\-\-$/ {in_yaml=1; next}
  in_yaml { if (/^\-\-\-$/){in_yaml=0; next} else next }
  !started && /^[A-Za-z_][-A-Za-z_0-9]*:[[:space:]]/ {next}
  {started=1; print}
' "$TMP_CAP1" > "$TMP_CAP1.clean" && mv "$TMP_CAP1.clean" "$TMP_CAP1"

# 4.3 remove se√ß√£o "Sugest√µes de linkagem" (daquele t√≠tulo at√© a pr√≥xima se√ß√£o de mesmo n√≠vel)
awk '
  BEGIN{drop=0}
  /^#{1,6}[[:space:]]+Sugest(√µes|oes) de linkagem[[:space:]]*$/ {drop=1; next}
  drop && /^#{1,6}[[:space:]]+/ {drop=0}
  !drop {print}
' "$TMP_CAP1" > "$TMP_CAP1.nolink" && mv "$TMP_CAP1.nolink" "$TMP_CAP1"

# 4.4 converte [[alvo|texto]] -> texto e [[alvo]] -> alvo
perl -CS -Mutf8 -i -pe 's/\[\[([^|\]]+)\|([^]]+)\]\]/\2/g; s/\[\[([^]]+)\]\]/\1/g;' "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1"

# --- 5) Gera o PDF ---
pandoc "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1" \
  --from=markdown \
  --pdf-engine=xelatex \
  --toc --toc-depth=2 \
  --number-sections -V secnumdepth=1 \
  -V documentclass=article \
  --include-in-header="$HOME/abnt_header.tex" \
  --include-before-body="$HOME/abnt_cover.tex" \
  -o "$OUT"

echo "‚úÖ PDF gerado em: $OUT"

# --- 6) Limpa tempor√°rios ---
rm -f "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1"
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/relatorio_cap1_min.sh"
```

### Como rodar


boa! esse erro do `mktemp` √© porque no macOS o template **precisa terminar em `XXXXXX`** (sem sufixo `.md`). vamos ajustar o script para usar o formato recomendado (`-t`) e s√≥ depois acrescentar `.md`.

cole estes comandos no terminal:

```bash

# 2) corrigir as duas linhas do mktemp no script

  -e 's#TMP_INTRO="$(mktemp .*intro_.*)"#TMP_INTRO="$(mktemp -t intro_md)"; TMP_INTRO="${TMP_INTRO}.md"; : > "$TMP_INTRO"#' \
  -e 's#TMP_CAP1="$(mktemp .*cap1_.*)"#TMP_CAP1="$(mktemp -t cap1_md)"; TMP_CAP1="${TMP_CAP1}.md"; : > "$TMP_CAP1"#' \
  "$HOME/relatorio_cap1_min.sh"

# 3) conferir (voc√™ deve ver as novas tr√™s instru√ß√µes em cada vari√°vel)
```

analise o print do pdf e avalie as dificuldades encontradas no momento e mencine os requisitos nao atingidos , para depois propor solu√ßoes

Analisando o print do PDF, vejo que, apesar de termos avan√ßado na formata√ß√£o ABNT e na montagem autom√°tica com `pandoc`, alguns problemas e requisitos n√£o foram totalmente atendidos. Vou listar os pontos por categoria:  

---

## **1. Problemas identificados no PDF**
### **a) P√°gina de rosto (capa ABNT)**
- O t√≠tulo ‚ÄúRelat√≥rio de Leitura ‚Äî The Character of Consciousness (Cap√≠tulo 1)‚Äù est√° correto, mas o espa√ßamento e a hierarquia visual n√£o seguem totalmente a ABNT (faltam margens e quebras de espa√ßo espec√≠ficas, e centraliza√ß√£o vertical precisa ser refinada).
- O local (‚ÄúS√£o Paulo‚Äù) e a data aparecem juntos sem espa√ßamento adequado ‚Äî na ABNT, ficam em linhas separadas, com espa√ßamento vertical de 3 a 5 linhas do fim da p√°gina.
- A capa n√£o tem o nome da institui√ß√£o no topo centralizado (que a ABNT exige em muitos modelos acad√™micos, mesmo para relat√≥rios de leitura).

---

### **b) Sum√°rio (TOC)**
- O sum√°rio est√° gerando metadados brutos (`"institui√ß√£o": ...`) que n√£o deveriam aparecer ‚Äî o script de sanitiza√ß√£o ainda n√£o removeu completamente essas linhas de metadados YAML.
- Os pontos de liga√ß√£o (....) no sum√°rio n√£o est√£o bem alinhados; provavelmente a configura√ß√£o do `toc` no `pandoc` precisa ser ajustada para a ABNT.
- H√° quebra de texto indevida nos itens do sum√°rio ‚Äî possivelmente causada por linhas muito longas sem tratamento.

---

### **c) Corpo do texto**
- As se√ß√µes est√£o numeradas corretamente, mas:

# Conven√ß√µes de arquivo (Obsidian)

```bash
ADVISOR="$ADVISOR_DEFAULT"
INSTIT="$INSTIT_DEFAULT"
CITY="$CITY_DEFAULT"
DATE_STR="$DATE_DEFAULT"
DRY="0"
VERBOSE="0"

while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
  case "$1" in
    --obra)       OBRA="$2"; shift 2;;
    --capitulos)  CAPS="$2"; shift 2;;
    --full)       FULL="1"; shift 1;;
    --title)      TITLE="$2"; shift 2;;
    --author)     AUTHOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --advisor)    ADVISOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --instit)     INSTIT="$2"; shift 2;;
    --city)       CITY="$2"; shift 2;;
    --date)       DATE_STR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --dry-run)    DRY="1"; shift 1;;
    --verbose)    VERBOSE="1"; shift 1;;
    -h|--help)    usage; exit 0;;
    *) echo "Flag desconhecida: $1"; usage; exit 2;;
  esac
done

[[ -z "$OBRA" ]] && { echo "‚ùå Falta --obra"; usage; exit 2; }
[[ ! -d "$OBRA" ]] && { echo "‚ùå Obra n√£o encontrada: $OBRA"; exit 2; }

# ========= Prepara√ß√£o de ambiente =========
export LANG="$LANG_ENV"
export LC_ALL="$LANG_ENV"

mkdir -p "$BUILD_DIR" "$PUB_DIR" "$CONF_DIR"

HEADER_TEX="$CONF_DIR/abnt_header.tex"
COVER_TEX="$CONF_DIR/abnt_cover.tex"

# ========= Cria header ABNT (se n√£o existir) =========
if [[ ! -f "$HEADER_TEX" ]]; then
  cat > "$HEADER_TEX" <<'TEX'
% ===== Locale/PT-BR, fontes e layout =====
\usepackage[brazil]{babel}
\usepackage{fontspec}
\setmainfont{Times New Roman}
\usepackage[a4paper,top=3cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=2cm]{geometry}
\usepackage{setspace}\onehalfspacing
\usepackage{indentfirst}
\setlength{\parindent}{1.25cm}
\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}

% ===== Listas do pandoc e bullets =====
\providecommand{\tightlist}{\setlength{\itemsep}{0pt}\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}}
\renewcommand{\labelitemi}{\textbullet}

% ===== Links discretos e pagina√ß√£o simples =====
\usepackage[hidelinks]{hyperref}
\usepackage{fancyhdr}
\pagestyle{fancy}\fancyhf{}\fancyfoot[C]{\thepage}
TEX
fi

# ========= Cria capa (din√¢mica por env) =========
cat > "$COVER_TEX" <<TEX
% p√°gina de rosto (sem n√∫mero)
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{center}
  {\Large \textbf{$TITLE}}\par
  \vspace{1.2cm}
  {$AUTHOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {Orientador: $ADVISOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {$INSTIT}\par
  \vfill
  {$CITY}\par
  {$DATE_STR}\par
\end{center}
\clearpage
TEX

# ========= Descobrir cap√≠tulos =========
if [[ "$FULL" == "1" ]]; then
  mapfile -t CAP_LIST < <(find "$OBRA" -maxdepth 1 -type d -name 'Cap_*' | sort)
elif [[ -n "$CAPS" ]]; then
  IFS=',' read -r -a CAP_ARR <<< "$CAPS"
  CAP_LIST=()
  for c in "${CAP_ARR[@]}"; do
    c_trim="${c#"${c%%[![:space:]]*}"}"; c_trim="${c_trim%"${c_trim##*[![:space:]]}"}"
    CAP_LIST+=("$OBRA/$c_trim")
  done
else
  CAP_LIST=("$OBRA/Cap_01")
fi

# ========= Sanitiza√ß√£o (python embutido) =========
sanitize_file() {
  local src="$1" dst="$2"
  /usr/bin/env python3 - <<'PY' "$src" "$dst"
import sys, pathlib, re, unicodedata
src = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[1]); dst = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[2])
text = src.read_bytes().decode("utf-8","ignore")
text = text.replace("\r\n","\n").replace("\r","\n")

# remove YAML front matter inicial
if text.startswith("---\n"):
    end = text.find("\n---", 4)
    if end != -1:
        text = text[end+4:].lstrip()

# remove linhas de metadados perdidas (Autor:, Orientador:...) s√≥ no topo
lines = text.split("\n")
i = 0
while i < min(30,len(lines)) and re.match(r'^\s*(Autor|Orientador|Institui..o|Local|Data)\s*:', lines[i], re.I):
    i += 1
text = "\n".join(lines[i:])

# remove controles/format (Cc/Cf), preservando \n \t
clean=[]
for ch in text:
    if ch in ("\n","\t"): clean.append(ch); continue
    cat = unicodedata.category(ch)
    if cat in ("Cc","Cf"): continue
    clean.append(ch)
text = "".join(clean)

# remove emojis/s√≠mbolos gr√°ficos problem√°ticos (alguns blocos comuns)
emoji = re.compile(r'[\U0001F000-\U0001FAFF\U0001F300-\U0001F6FF\U0001F900-\U0001F9FF\u2600-\u26FF]')
text = emoji.sub("", text)

# converter [[alvo|texto]] -> texto; [[alvo]] -> alvo
text = re.sub(r'\[\[([^|\]]+)\|([^]]+)\]\]', r'\2', text)
text = re.sub(r'\[\[([^]]+)\]\]', r'\1', text)

dst.write_text(text, encoding="utf-8")
PY
}

# ========= Constru√ß√£o da lista de arquivos (intro + cap√≠tulos) =========
INPUTS=()
INTRO_MD="$OBRA/intro.md"
if [[ -f "$INTRO_MD" ]]; then
  TMP_INTRO="$(mktemp "$BUILD_DIR/intro_XXXXXX.md")"
  sanitize_file "$INTRO_MD" "$TMP_INTRO"
  INPUTS+=("$TMP_INTRO")
fi

for CAP_DIR in "${CAP_LIST[@]}"; do
  [[ -d "$CAP_DIR" ]] || { echo "‚ö†Ô∏è Ignorando inexistente: $CAP_DIR"; continue; }
  # tenta nomes comuns de arquivo de conte√∫do
  for f in "Conceitos_Chave.md" "capitulo.md" "index.md"; do
    SRC="$CAP_DIR/$f"
    if [[ -f "$SRC" ]]; then
      TMP_CAP="$(mktemp "$BUILD_DIR/cap_XXXXXX.md")"
      sanitize_file "$SRC" "$TMP_CAP"
      INPUTS+=("$TMP_CAP")
    fi
  done
done

[[ ${#INPUTS[@]} -eq 0 ]] && { echo "‚ùå Nenhum .md encontrado para compilar."; exit 3; }

# ========= Arquivo de sa√≠da =========
OBRA_NAME="$(basename "$OBRA")"
if [[ "$FULL" == "1" ]]; then
  OUT_PDF="$PUB_DIR/${OBRA_NAME}_OBRA_INTEIRA_$(date +%Y-%m-%d).pdf"
else
  # usa primeiro cap√≠tulo da lista no nome
  CAP_TAG="$(basename "${CAP_LIST[0]}")"
  OUT_PDF="$PUB_DIR/${OBRA_NAME}_${CAP_TAG}_$(date +%Y-%m-%d).pdf"
fi

# ========= Mostrar plano (dry-run) =========
if [[ "$DRY" == "1" ]]; then
  echo "DRY-RUN"
  printf "Obra: %s\n" "$OBRA"
  printf "Cap√≠tulos: \n"; printf "  - %s\n" "${CAP_LIST[@]}"
  printf "Inputs sanitizados (%d):\n" "${#INPUTS[@]}"; printf "  - %s\n" "${INPUTS[@]}"
  printf "Sa√≠da: %s\n" "$OUT_PDF"
  exit 0
fi

# ========= Compila√ß√£o (Pandoc) =========
LOG="$OUT_PDF.log"
PANDOC_OPTS=(
  "--from=markdown"
  "--pdf-engine=xelatex"
  "--toc" "--toc-depth=2"
  "--number-sections" "-V" "secnumdepth=1"
  "-V" "documentclass=article"
  "--include-in-header=$HEADER_TEX"
  "--include-before-body=$COVER_TEX"
  "-V" "mainfont=Times New Roman" "-V" "fontsize=12pt"
)

# cita√ß√µes (opcional)
if [[ -f "$ZOTERO_JSON" && -f "$CSL_STYLE" ]]; then
  PANDOC_OPTS+=( "--citeproc" "--bibliography=$ZOTERO_JSON" "--csl=$CSL_STYLE" )
fi

# verbosidade
[[ "$VERBOSE" == "1" ]] && set -x
if ! pandoc "${INPUTS[@]}" "${PANDOC_OPTS[@]}" -o "$OUT_PDF" 2> "$LOG"; then
  set +x || true
  echo "‚ùå Erro ao gerar PDF. Log: $LOG"
  exit 4
fi
set +x || true

echo "‚úÖ PDF gerado em: $OUT_PDF"

# ========= Manifesto =========
MANIFEST="$PUB_DIR/manifest.jsonl"  # NDJSON (uma linha por item)
HASH="$(/usr/bin/shasum -a 256 "$OUT_PDF" | awk '{print $1}')"
NOW="$(date -Is)"
printf '{"obra":"%s","caps":%s,"arquivo":"%s","sha256":"%s","gerado_em":"%s","title":"%s","author":"%s","advisor":"%s","instit":"%s","city":"%s"}\n' \
  "$OBRA_NAME" \
  "$(printf '['; for d in "${CAP_LIST[@]}"; do printf '"%s",' "$(basename "$d")"; done | sed 's/,$//'; printf ']')" \
  "$OUT_PDF" "$HASH" "$NOW" \
  "$TITLE" "$AUTHOR" "$ADVISOR" "$INSTIT" "$CITY" >> "$MANIFEST"

# ========= Limpeza =========
# remove apenas os tempor√°rios criados nesta execu√ß√£o
for f in "${INPUTS[@]}"; do
  case "$f" in
    "$BUILD_DIR"/*) rm -f "$f" ;;
  esac
done

# ========= Abertura (macOS) =========
open "$OUT_PDF" >/dev/null 2>&1 || true
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/relatorio.sh"
echo "‚úî Instalado: $HOME/relatorio.sh"
```

parts:
perfeito ‚Äî vamos trocar o ‚Äústub‚Äù por um script completo, j√° com sanitiza√ß√£o de Markdown + capa ABNT + Pandoc.

---

### 1) Utilit√°rios (sanitizador de Markdown)
```bash
# cria pasta de bin√°rios do usu√°rio (se n√£o existir)
mkdir -p ~/bin

# utilit√°rio: limpa YAML, controles, emojis e [[wikilinks]]
cat > ~/bin/md_sanitize.py <<'PY'
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import sys, pathlib, re, unicodedata

YAML_RE = re.compile(r"(?s)\A---\n.*?\n---\n")
EARLY_RE = re.compile(r"(?im)^(?:title|autor|author|date|orientador|instituicao)\s*:\s*.*$\n?")
WIKILINK_RE = re.compile(r"\[\[([^|\]]+)\|([^]]+)\]\]|\[\[([^]]+)\]\]")

# blocos de emojis/s√≠mbolos gr√°ficos comuns que quebram PDF
EMOJI_RE = re.compile(
    "[" +
    "\U0001F000-\U0001FAFF" +  # Mahjong‚Ä¶ s√≠mbolos
    "\U0001F300-\U0001F6FF" +
    "\U0001F900-\U0001F9FF" +
    "\u2600-\u26FF" +         # Weather etc.
    "]", flags=re.UNICODE
)

def clean_text(s: str) -> str:
    s = s.replace("\r\n", "\n").replace("\r", "\n")
    s = YAML_RE.sub("", s, count=1)
    s = EARLY_RE.sub("", s)
    # remove VS16 e categorias de controle/format (Cc/Cf), preservando \n e \t
    out = []
    for ch in s:
        if ch in ("\n", "\t"):
            out.append(ch)
            continue
        cat = unicodedata.category(ch)
        if cat in ("Cc", "Cf"):
            continue
        out.append(ch)
    s = "".join(out)
    # remove emojis
    s = EMOJI_RE.sub("", s)
    # [[alvo|texto]] -> texto ; [[alvo]] -> alvo
    def repl(m):
        if m.group(1) and m.group(2):  # [[a|b]]
            return m.group(2)
        return m.group(3) or ""
    s = WIKILINK_RE.sub(repl, s)
    # linhas horizontais sozinhas (---, ___, ***)
    s = re.sub(r"(?m)^\s*(?:-{3,}|_{3,}|\*{3,})\s*$", "", s)
    return s

def clean_file(p: pathlib.Path):
    raw = p.read_bytes()
    txt = raw.decode("utf-8", "ignore")
    p.write_text(clean_text(txt), encoding="utf-8")

def main():
    if len(sys.argv) < 2:
        print("uso: md_sanitize.py arq1.md [arq2.md ...]", file=sys.stderr); sys.exit(2)
    for a in sys.argv[1:]:
        clean_file(pathlib.Path(a))
    print("OK: arquivos limpos.")
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
PY
chmod +x ~/bin/md_sanitize.py
```

### 2) Header ABNT (reaproveit√°vel)

```bash
% ===== Listas do pandoc e bullets =====
\providecommand{\tightlist}{\setlength{\itemsep}{0pt}\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}}
\renewcommand{\labelitemi}{\textbullet}

% ===== Links discretos e pagina√ß√£o simples =====
```

### 3) Script principal (`~/relatorio.sh`)
```bash
cat > "$HOME/relatorio.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# -------- par√¢metros (long options) --------
OBRA=""
CAPS=""
TITLE="Relat√≥rio de Leitura"
AUTHOR="Marcos Antonio de Menezes"
ADVISOR="Prof. Walter Chesnut"
INSTIT="Universidade de S√£o Paulo ‚Äî Instituto de Ci√™ncias Biom√©dicas (ICB‚ÄëUSP)"
CITY="S√£o Paulo"
DATE="$(date +%d/%m/%Y)"
OUT="$HOME/Relatorio.pdf"

while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
  case "$1" in
    --obra)        OBRA="$2"; shift 2;;
    --capitulos)   CAPS="$2"; shift 2;;   # ex: "Cap_01,Cap_02" ou "Cap_01"
    --title)       TITLE="$2"; shift 2;;
    --author)      AUTHOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --orientador)  ADVISOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --instituicao) INSTIT="$2"; shift 2;;
    --local)       CITY="$2"; shift 2;;
    --date)        DATE="$2"; shift 2;;
    --out)         OUT="$2"; shift 2;;
    -h|--help)
      echo "Uso: $0 --obra <pasta_obra> --capitulos \"Cap_01,Cap_02\" [--title ...] [--out ...]"
      exit 0;;
    *) echo "Par√¢metro desconhecido: $1"; exit 2;;
  esac
done

if [[ -z "$OBRA" || -z "$CAPS" ]]; then
  echo "‚ùå Informe --obra e --capitulos"; exit 2
fi
if [[ ! -d "$OBRA" ]]; then
  echo "‚ùå Pasta da obra n√£o encontrada: $OBRA"; exit 2
fi

# -------- localizar fontes --------
INTRO="$OBRA/intro.md"
if [[ ! -f "$INTRO" ]]; then
  # fallback: busca arquivo contendo 'intro' no nome
  INTRO=$(find "$OBRA" -maxdepth 1 -type f -iname '*intro*.md' | head -n1 || true)
fi
[[ -f "$INTRO" ]] || { echo "‚ùå intro.md n√£o encontrado na raiz da obra."; exit 2; }

IFS=',' read -r -a CAP_ARRAY <<< "$CAPS"
FOUND_MD=()

for token in "${CAP_ARRAY[@]}"; do
  token_trim="$(echo "$token" | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//; s/[[:space:]]*$//')"
  # aceita v√°rios padr√µes comuns (Cap_01 / Cap√≠tulo_01* / 01_*)
  matches=$(find "$OBRA" -type d \( -iname "${token_trim}" -o -iname "*${token_trim}*" \) -print 2>/dev/null || true)
  if [[ -z "$matches" ]]; then
    echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Nenhuma pasta para cap√≠tulo: $token_trim"
    continue
  fi
  while IFS= read -r d; do
    while IFS= read -r f; do
      FOUND_MD+=("$f")
    done < <(find "$d" -type f -name '*.md' | sort)
  done <<< "$matches"
done

if [[ ${#FOUND_MD[@]} -eq 0 ]]; then
  echo "‚ùå Nenhum .md encontrado nos cap√≠tulos informados."; exit 2
fi

# -------- tempor√°rios --------
TMP_INTRO="$(mktemp /tmp/intro_XXXXXX.md)"
TMP_LIST=()
for i in "${!FOUND_MD[@]}"; do
  TMP_LIST+=("$(mktemp /tmp/cap_${i}_XXXXXX.md)")
done

# -------- sanitiza√ß√£o --------
cp -f "$INTRO" "$TMP_INTRO"
~/bin/md_sanitize.py "$TMP_INTRO" >/dev/null
for i in "${!FOUND_MD[@]}"; do
  cp -f "${FOUND_MD[$i]}" "${TMP_LIST[$i]}"
  ~/bin/md_sanitize.py "${TMP_LIST[$i]}" >/dev/null
done

# -------- capa din√¢mica --------
TMP_COVER="$(mktemp /tmp/cover_XXXXXX.tex)"
cat > "$TMP_COVER" <<TEX
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{center}
  {\Large \textbf{$TITLE}}\par
  \vspace{1.2cm}
  {$AUTHOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {Orientador: $ADVISOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {$INSTIT}\par
  \vfill
  {$CITY}\par
  {$DATE}\par
\end{center}
\clearpage
TEX

# -------- chamada pandoc --------
echo "‚ñ∂ Gerando PDF‚Ä¶"
pandoc "$TMP_INTRO" "${TMP_LIST[@]}" \
  --from=markdown \
  --pdf-engine=xelatex \
  --toc --toc-depth=2 \
  --number-sections -V secnumdepth=1 \
  -V documentclass=article \
  -V mainfont="Times New Roman" -V fontsize=12pt \
  --include-in-header="$HOME/abnt_header.tex" \
  --include-before-body="$TMP_COVER" \
  -o "$OUT"

echo "‚úÖ PDF gerado em: $OUT"
open "$OUT" >/dev/null 2>&1 || true

# -------- limpeza --------
rm -f "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_COVER" "${TMP_LIST[@]}"
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/relatorio.sh"
```

### 4) Rodar (seu caso de teste)

---

### Observa√ß√µes r√°pidas
- O sanitizador remove emojis/controles e converte `[[alvo|texto]]` ‚Üí `texto`, `[[alvo]]` ‚Üí `alvo`.

thoughts.content: O script gerou um relat√≥rio de v√°rias p√°ginas com sum√°rio, mas surgiram avisos de caracteres faltando, como o h√≠fen n√£o separ√°vel (U+2011) e o emoji de interroga√ß√£o (U+2753) no Times New Roman. Preciso garantir que a sanitiza√ß√£o remova emojis e substitua o h√≠fen. A formata√ß√£o deve seguir as normas ABNT, incluindo margens, fontes, espa√ßamento de 1,5, e uma capa com informa√ß√µes da institui√ß√£o. Al√©m disso, o sum√°rio precisa estar em portugu√™s e com a formata√ß√£o correta.

Percebi que o "Sum√°rio" apresenta um par√°grafo grande de metadados, sugerindo que a supress√£o do YAML n√£o foi completamente aplicada aos cap√≠tulos compilados. O sanitizer provavelmente n√£o tratou algumas linhas corretamente. Precisamos remover se√ß√µes como "Metadados adicionais", "Sugest√µes de linkagem", "Insights" e "Perguntas". Vamos filtrar e eliminar emojis de lista e quest√µes.

Encontramos alguns problemas com caracteres como U+2011 (h√≠fen n√£o separ√°vel). Proponho substituir por h√≠fen normal ou en dash e remover emojis como ‚ùì. Al√©m disso, a capa deve seguir o estilo ABNT, com a personaliza√ß√£o do sum√°rio para "Sum√°rio" e n√∫mero de se√ß√µes at√© o segundo n√≠vel. Aproxima√ß√µes de formata√ß√£o oficiais tamb√©m precisam ser consideradas.

parts:
√≥timo ‚Äî o PDF saiu, mas d√° pra ver (e os avisos confirmam) que ainda faltam alguns acertos. Aqui vai um diagn√≥stico r√°pido + o que ajustar j√° no terminal.

# O que ainda est√° fora do lugar
1) **Avisos de fonte**
   - `U+2011` (non‚Äëbreaking hyphen) ‚Üí Times New Roman n√£o tem essa forma; trocamos por h√≠fen normal.
   - `U+2753` (‚ùì) ‚Üí emoji; deve ser removido do .md (n√£o faz parte do relat√≥rio).

2) **TOC em ingl√™s (‚ÄúContents‚Äù)**  
   Queremos **‚ÄúSum√°rio‚Äù** sempre.

3) **Lixo de metadados no TOC/p√°gina 1**  
   Est√° caindo um bloco com chaves como `institui√ß√£o:`, `autor:`, etc. Isso √© YAML/‚Äúmetadados adicionais‚Äù vindo do Obsidian/Typora. Precisamos filtr√°‚Äëlo.

4) **Se√ß√µes que n√£o fazem parte do relat√≥rio**  
   Exemplos: ‚ÄúMetadados adicionais‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúSugest√µes de linkagem‚Äù, ‚ÄúPerguntas/Insights‚Äù etc. Elas est√£o no .md para navega√ß√£o, mas n√£o devem ir ao PDF.

5) **ABNT/USP ‚Äì cobrimos o b√°sico**, mas ainda faltam pequenos detalhes est√©ticos (ex.: ‚ÄúSum√°rio‚Äù PT‚ÄëBR, limpeza total de emojis/s√≠mbolos, padroniza√ß√£o de tra√ßos).

---

# Corre√ß√µes (passo a passo, s√≥ terminal)

## 1) Deixe o cabe√ßalho LaTeX mais ‚ÄúPT‚ÄëBR‚Äù e sem esses s√≠mbolos
```bash
cat > "$HOME/abnt_header.tex" <<'TEX'
\usepackage[brazil]{babel}
\usepackage{fontspec}
\setmainfont{Times New Roman}
\usepackage[a4paper,top=3cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=2cm]{geometry}
\usepackage{setspace}\onehalfspacing
\usepackage{indentfirst}
\setlength{\parindent}{1.25cm}
\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}

% Listas geradas pelo pandoc
\providecommand{\tightlist}{\setlength{\itemsep}{0pt}\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}}
\renewcommand{\labelitemi}{\textbullet}

% Sum√°rio em PT-BR
\addto\captionsbrazil{\renewcommand{\contentsname}{Sum√°rio}}

% Links discretos e pagina√ß√£o
\usepackage[hidelinks]{hyperref}
\usepackage{fancyhdr}
\pagestyle{fancy}\fancyhf{}\fancyfoot[C]{\thepage}
TEX
```

## 2) Sanear os .md antes de compilar (sem tocar nos originais)
Vamos criar um ‚Äúmini‚Äësanitizador‚Äù r√°pido que:
- troca U+2011 por h√≠fen,
- remove emojis/‚ùì,
- remove YAML no topo,
- apaga se√ß√µes inteiras como ‚ÄúMetadados adicionais‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúSugest√µes de linkagem‚Äù, ‚ÄúPerguntas‚Äù, ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù.

```bash
cat > "$HOME/bin/md_filter.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail
in="$1"; out="$2"

# 1) troca non-breaking hyphen por h√≠fen normal
perl -CS -Mutf8 -pe 's/\x{2011}/-/g' "$in" > "$out.tmp1"

# 2) remove emojis e varia√ß√µes (inclui ‚ùì)
perl -CS -Mutf8 -pe 's/\x{FE0F}//g; s/\p{Extended_Pictographic}//g' "$out.tmp1" > "$out.tmp2"

# 3) remove bloco YAML do topo (--- ... ---)
awk '
BEGIN{in_yaml=0; firstnonblank=0}
{
  if(!firstnonblank && $0 ~ /^---[[:space:]]*$/){in_yaml=1; next}
  if(in_yaml && $0 ~ /^---[[:space:]]*$/){in_yaml=0; next}
  if(!in_yaml){
    if($0 ~ /[^[:space:]]/) firstnonblank=1
    print
  }
}' "$out.tmp2" > "$out.tmp3"

# 4) drop de se√ß√µes inteiras por t√≠tulo (at√© pr√≥ximo ## do mesmo n√≠vel)
perl -CS -Mutf8 -0777 -pe '
 s/^##[ \t]*(Metadados adicionais(?:.*)?)\R(?:.*\R)*?(?=^##[ \t]+|\z)//mg;
 s/^##[ \t]*(Sugest(√µes|oes) de linkagem(?:.*)?)\R(?:.*\R)*?(?=^##[ \t]+|\z)//mg;
 s/^##[ \t]*(Perguntas(?:.*)?)\R(?:.*\R)*?(?=^##[ \t]+|\z)//mg;
 s/^##[ \t]*(Insights?(?:.*)?)\R(?:.*\R)*?(?=^##[ \t]+|\z)//mg;
' "$out.tmp3" > "$out"

rm -f "$out.tmp1" "$out.tmp2" "$out.tmp3"
BASH
chmod +x "$HOME/bin/md_filter.sh"
```

## 3) Gerar arquivos tempor√°rios limpos e compilar
> (mant√©m seus .md intactos; use os *paths* da sua obra)

```bash
OBRA="$HOME/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Pessoal/USP/Projeto_ICB_Consci√™ncia/ICB-USP_Consci√™ncia/01_The_Character_of_Consciousness"
CAPDIR="$OBRA/Cap√≠tulo_01_Facing_Up_to_the_Problem_of_Consciousness"

INTRO="$OBRA/intro.md"
CAP1="$CAPDIR/Conceitos_Chave.md"

TMP_INTRO=$(mktemp /tmp/intro_XXXXXX.md)
TMP_CAP1=$(mktemp /tmp/cap1_XXXXXX.md)

"$HOME/bin/md_filter.sh" "$INTRO" "$TMP_INTRO"
"$HOME/bin/md_filter.sh" "$CAP1"  "$TMP_CAP1"

OUT="$HOME/Relatorio_Cap1.pdf"
TITLE="Relat√≥rio de Leitura ‚Äî The Character of Consciousness (Cap√≠tulo 1)"
AUTHOR="Marcos Antonio de Menezes"
ADVISOR="Prof. Walter Chesnut"
INSTIT="Universidade de S√£o Paulo ‚Äî Instituto de Ci√™ncias Biom√©dicas (ICB‚ÄëUSP)"
CITY="S√£o Paulo"
DATE="$(date +%d/%m/%Y)"

cat > "$HOME/abnt_cover.tex" <<TEX
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{center}
  {\Large \textbf{$TITLE}}\par
  \vspace{1.2cm}
  {$AUTHOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {Orientador: $ADVISOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {$INSTIT}\par
  \vfill
  {$CITY}\par
  {$DATE}\par
\end{center}
\clearpage
TEX

pandoc "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1" \
  --from=markdown \
  --pdf-engine=xelatex \
  --toc --toc-depth=2 \
  --number-sections -V secnumdepth=1 \
  -V documentclass=article \
  --include-in-header="$HOME/abnt_header.tex" \
  --include-before-body="$HOME/abnt_cover.tex" \
  -o "$OUT" && open "$OUT"

rm -f "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1"
```

## Corre√ß√£o (troca o filtro por um √∫nico script robusto)

### 1) Substitua o `md_filter.sh` por esta vers√£o (100% Python dentro do shell)

Ela:
- l√™ bytes e tenta **UTF‚Äë8**; se falhar, **decodifica como Latin‚Äë1** e converte para UTF‚Äë8;
- normaliza **NFC**;
- **remove Cc/Cf** (C0/C1 e formatadores) preservando `\n` e `\t`;
- remove **emoji/VS16**;
- troca **U+2011** por `-`;
- converte **aspas/tra√ßos Windows‚Äë1252** para Unicode;
- remove **YAML** do topo;
- **corta se√ß√µes** ‚ÄúMetadados adicionais‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúSugest√µes de linkagem‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúPerguntas‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúInsights‚Ä¶‚Äù.

```bash
cat > "$HOME/bin/md_filter.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail
in="$1"; out="$2"

python3 - <<'PY' "$in" "$out"
import sys, re, unicodedata, pathlib

src = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[1])
dst = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[2])

raw = src.read_bytes()
# 1) decodifica: tenta UTF-8; se falhar, usa latin-1 e converte p/ UTF-8
try:
    text = raw.decode('utf-8')
except UnicodeDecodeError:
    text = raw.decode('latin-1')

# 2) normaliza finais de linha + NFC
text = text.replace('\r\n','\n').replace('\r','\n')
text = unicodedata.normalize('NFC', text)

# 3) troca caracteres problem√°ticos / Windows-1252 common
subs = {
    '\u2011':'-',  # non-breaking hyphen -> hyphen
    '\u2013':'‚Äì',  # en dash (mant√©m)
    '\u2014':'‚Äî',  # em dash (mant√©m)
    '\u2018':'‚Äò', '\u2019':'‚Äô',  # single quotes
    '\u201C':'‚Äú', '\u201D':'‚Äù',  # double quotes
}
for k,v in subs.items():
    text = text.replace(k, v)

# 4) remove VS16 e EMOJI/s√≠mbolos gr√°ficos
emoji_re = re.compile(r'[\U0001F000-\U0001FAFF\U0001F300-\U0001F6FF\U0001F900-\U0001F9FF\u2600-\u26FF]')
text = text.replace('\uFE0F','')
text = emoji_re.sub('', text)

# 5) remove categorias Cc/Cf exceto \n e \t
cleaned = []
for ch in text:
    cat = unicodedata.category(ch)
    if ch in ('\n','\t'): 
        cleaned.append(ch)
    elif cat in ('Cc','Cf'):
        continue
    else:
        cleaned.append(ch)
text = ''.join(cleaned)

# 6) remove bloco YAML inicial (--- ... ---)
lines = text.split('\n')
i = 0
while i < len(lines) and lines[i].strip()=='':
    i += 1
if i < len(lines) and lines[i].strip() == '---':
    j = i+1
    while j < len(lines) and lines[j].strip() != '---':
        j += 1
    if j < len(lines):
        lines = lines[:i] + lines[j+1:]
text = '\n'.join(lines)

# 7) drop de se√ß√µes inteiras por t√≠tulo (## ... at√© pr√≥ximo ##)
def drop_section(txt, pattern):
    return re.sub(
        rf'(?ms)^\#\#\s*{pattern}\s*\n(?:.*?\n)(?=^\#\#\s|\Z)', 
        '', txt
    )

for pat in [r'Metadados adicionais.*', r'Sugest(√µes|oes) de linkagem.*', r'Perguntas.*', r'Insights?.*']:
    text = drop_section(text, pat)

dst.write_text(text, encoding='utf-8')
```

## 1) Atualize o filtro para remover o ‚Äúpar√°grafo de metadados‚Äù e linhas `---`

> Substitui o arquivo `~/bin/md_filter.sh` pela vers√£o com duas regras novas:
> - Remove um **par√°grafo inicial** que agregue chaves como `instituicao:`, `titulo:`, `autor:`, `orientador:`, `lang:`, `documentclass:`, etc.

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail
in="$1"; out="$2"

python3 - <<'PY' "$in" "$out"
import sys, re, unicodedata, pathlib

src = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[1])
dst = pathlib.Path(sys.argv[2])

raw = src.read_bytes()
# 1) decodifica√ß√£o robusta

    text = raw.decode('utf-8')
except UnicodeDecodeError:
    text = raw.decode('latin-1')

# 2) normaliza√ß√£o
text = text.replace('\r\n','\n').replace('\r','\n')
text = unicodedata.normalize('NFC', text)

# 3) trocas √∫teis (h√≠fen NBSP etc.)
text = text.replace('\u2011','-')  # non‚Äëbreaking hyphen -> '-'
for a,b in [('‚Äú','‚Äú'),('‚Äù','‚Äù'),('‚Äò','‚Äò'),('‚Äô','‚Äô'),('‚Äì','‚Äì'),('‚Äî','‚Äî')]:
    text = text.replace(a,b)

# 4) limpa emoji/VS16
emoji_re = re.compile(r'[\U0001F000-\U0001FAFF\U0001F300-\U0001F6FF\U0001F900-\U0001F9FF\u2600-\u26FF]')
text = text.replace('\uFE0F','')
text = emoji_re.sub('', text)

# 5) remove Cc/Cf, preserva \n e \t
clean = []
for ch in text:
    cat = unicodedata.category(ch)
    if ch in ('\n','\t'):
        clean.append(ch)
    elif cat in ('Cc','Cf'):
        continue
    else:
        clean.append(ch)
text = ''.join(clean)

# 6) remove bloco YAML inicial (--- ... ---)
lines = text.split('\n')
i = 0
while i < len(lines) and lines[i].strip()=='':
    i += 1
if i < len(lines) and lines[i].strip() == '---':
    j = i+1
    while j < len(lines) and lines[j].strip() != '---':
        j += 1
    if j < len(lines):
        lines = lines[:i] + lines[j+1:]
text = '\n'.join(lines)

# 7) remove PAR√ÅGRAFO de metadados ‚Äúinline‚Äù (instituicao: ... | titulo: ... | ...)
md_keys = r'(instituic[a√£]o|t[i√≠]tulo|autor|orientador|local|date|lang|documentclass|fontsize|mainfont|classoption|preambulo|tags)'
# pega o primeiro par√°grafo n√£o-vazio
paras = re.split(r'\n\s*\n', text, maxsplit=1)
if paras:
    p0 = paras[0].strip()
    # se tem v√°rias ocorr√™ncias chave:valor separadas por | ou espa√ßo, removemos
    if re.search(rf'\b{md_keys}\b\s*:', p0, re.IGNORECASE) and ('|' in p0 or ':' in p0):
        text = paras[1] if len(paras) > 1 else ''

# 8) remove linhas horizontais puras (---, ___, ***)
text = re.sub(r'(?m)^\s*(?:-{3,}|_{3,}|\*{3,})\s*$', '', text)

# 9) drop de se√ß√µes inteiras por t√≠tulo (## ... at√© pr√≥ximo ##)
def drop_section(txt, pattern):
    return re.sub(rf'(?ms)^\#\#\s*{pattern}\s*\n(?:.*?\n)(?=^\#\#\s|\Z)', '', txt)

for pat in [r'Metadados adicionais.*', r'Sugest(√µes|oes) de linkagem.*', r'Perguntas.*', r'Insights?.*']:
    text = drop_section(text, pat)

dst.write_text(text, encoding='utf-8')
```

perfeito ‚Äî vou colocar a **normaliza√ß√£o dos h√≠fens/espacos especiais** direto no fluxo do `relatorio.sh`, usando s√≥ comandos de terminal e `cat`.

## 1) Criar um helper de normaliza√ß√£o
Ele troca:
- h√≠fen n√£o‚Äëquebr√°vel (U+2011), en‚Äëdash (U+2013) e em‚Äëdash (U+2014) ‚Üí `-`
- espa√ßo n√£o‚Äëquebr√°vel (U+00A0) ‚Üí espa√ßo comum

```bash
mkdir -p "$HOME/bin"

cat > "$HOME/bin/normalize_vars.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
normalize_vars() {
  # lista de vari√°veis de capa/metadados a normalizar
  local vars=(TITLE AUTHOR ADVISOR INSTIT CITY DATE)
  local v val
  for v in "${vars[@]}"; do
    # pega o valor atual da vari√°vel
    val="$(eval "printf '%s' \"\${$v}\"")"
    # normaliza h√≠fens e espa√ßos "especiais"
    val="${val//$'\u2011'/-}"   # non-breaking hyphen ‚Üí -
    val="${val//$'\u2013'/-}"   # en dash ‚Üí -
    val="${val//$'\u2014'/-}"   # em dash ‚Üí -
    val="${val//$'\u00A0'/ }"   # NBSP ‚Üí espa√ßo comum
    # grava de volta
    eval "$v=\"\$val\""
  done
}
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/bin/normalize_vars.sh"
```

normalize_vars() {

Marcos, olhando o que voc√™ me enviou (PDF com marca√ß√µes + c√≥digo atual), eu identifiquei **tr√™s causas distintas** para os problemas:

---

## **1Ô∏è‚É£ Problema t√©cnico ‚Äî U+2011 persistente**
- Mesmo com o `\newunicodechar{-}{-}` no LaTeX, o XeLaTeX ainda acusa **"Missing character: U+2011"**.
- Isso acontece porque o filtro `normalize_text.sh` n√£o est√° pegando todos os casos antes do Pandoc.
- Solu√ß√£o: refor√ßar a normaliza√ß√£o **antes mesmo de salvar no `.md`**, usando `perl` puro (que n√£o quebra com UTF-8 como o `awk` que deu o erro `multibyte conversion failure`).

---

## **2Ô∏è‚É£ Problema estrutural ‚Äî excesso de conte√∫do irrelevante para relat√≥rio**
- O que voc√™ marcou de amarelo no PDF inclui:
  - Blocos de **links completos de arquivos** (`file:///...`) ‚Äî n√£o s√£o √∫teis no relat√≥rio final.
  - Blocos de metadados do Obsidian que vazaram para o corpo.
  - Texto redundante ou repetitivo de "conceitos chave" j√° explicados em outro ponto.
- Isso indica que o script n√£o est√° **limpando blocos YAML** e nem **filtrando tipos de se√ß√£o**.

---

## **3Ô∏è‚É£ Problema conceitual ‚Äî padroniza√ß√£o de relat√≥rio ABNT**
- Seu relat√≥rio mistura:
  - Texto corrido (bom).
  - Listas desnecess√°rias de t√≥picos de anota√ß√µes pessoais.
  - Repeti√ß√£o de t√≠tulos de se√ß√µes originais (n√£o precisaria no relat√≥rio).
- Precisamos criar um **filtro de se√ß√µes essenciais**:
  - Introdu√ß√£o breve.
  - Resumo por t√≥picos claros.
  - Quest√µes de reflex√£o (opcional).
  - Trechos relevantes.
  - Refer√™ncias.

---

## **Plano de corre√ß√£o**
1. **Substituir o trecho `awk` por `perl` puro** para evitar o erro `multibyte conversion failure` e remover todos os U+2011 antes do Pandoc.
2. **Adicionar um filtro de se√ß√µes** no `normalize_text.sh` para eliminar:
   - Links `file:///...`
   - Qualquer linha que comece com `[` e termine com `]` se n√£o for cita√ß√£o.
   - Cabe√ßalhos como `### Tags:` ou `## Sum√°rio`.
3. **Criar um modo "essencial"** no script do relat√≥rio, para que s√≥ entre no PDF o que for relevante.

---

Se quiser, eu j√° te passo **um `normalize_text.sh` revisado** que:
- Remove U+2011 sem deixar passar para o LaTeX.
- Descarta blocos YAML e linhas de sistema do Obsidian.
- Filtra se√ß√µes n√£o essenciais para relat√≥rio.

thoughts.summary: Descrevendo o processo de normaliza√ß√£o de texto
thoughts.content: Precisamos atualizar o script normalize_text.sh, incluindo md_filter e algumas orienta√ß√µes. Vou fornecer os comandos para terminal, come√ßando com o uso de `perl` para processar o arquivo inteiro. A ideia √© remover o BOM, normalizar os fins de linha, e retirar blocos YAML e outros metadados. Vou tamb√©m adicionar comandos e uma linha no `relatorio.sh` para salvar backups e ajustes nos links do Obsidian.

Vamos criar um regex para remover linhas que contenham v√°rias ocorr√™ncias de "key:value". Isso vai detectar padr√µes como [\pL ]+:\s e excluir par√°grafos inteiros com 3 ou mais ocorr√™ncias. Al√©m disso, vamos remover links, temas em markdown e cabe√ßalhos espec√≠ficos, como "Metadados adicionais" e "Sugest√µes de linkagem", mantendo campos mais relevantes.

parts:
perfeito ‚Äî vamos atacar isso de forma cir√∫rgica. Abaixo vai um pacote pequeno (s√≥ **um** normalizador forte em Perl) + como plugar no `relatorio.sh`. Ele resolve:

- remo√ß√£o **definitiva** do U+2011 (e afins) ‚Üí some o warning do LaTeX  
- limpeza dos **blocos YAML** e ‚Äúpar√°grafos-metadados‚Äù (aquele tijolo com `chave: valor | chave: valor ‚Ä¶`)  
- poda de **se√ß√µes n√£o‚Äëessenciais** (‚ÄúMetadados adicionais‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúSugest√µes de linkagem‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúInsights‚Ä¶‚Äù)  
- convers√£o de **links** (Markdown e Obsidian) para texto limpo  
- remo√ß√£o de linhas ‚Äúdecorativas‚Äù (`---`, `___`, `***`) e URLs soltas

---

# 1) Normalizador √∫nico (substitui o anterior)

```bash
mkdir -p "$HOME/bin"

cat > "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Uso: normalize_text.sh arquivo1.md [arquivo2.md ...]

perl -CS -Mutf8 -0777 -i -pe '
  # --- 0) normaliza finais de linha e remove BOM
  s/\r\n?/\n/g;
  s/\A\x{FEFF}//;

  # --- 1) remove front-matter YAML (--- ... --- no in√≠cio do arquivo)
  s/\A---\n.*?\n---\n?//s;

  # --- 2) remove par√°grafos que s√£o "blocos de metadados" (>=3 ocorr√™ncias chave: valor)
  $_ = join("\n\n",
    grep {
      my $p = $_;
      my $hits = () = ($p =~ /(^|[ \t\|])\p{L}[\p{L}\p{M}\s\-]*:\s+/mg);
      $hits < 3   # mant√©m se tiver menos de 3 pares chave:valor
    } split(/\n{2,}/)
  );

  # --- 3) converte links
  s/\[\[([^|\]]+)\|([^]]+)\]\]/$2/g;  # [[alvo|texto]] -> texto
  s/\[\[([^]]+)\]\]/$1/g;            # [[alvo]] -> alvo
  s/\[([^\]]+)\]\((?:[^)]+)\)/$1/g;  # [texto](url) -> texto

  # --- 4) remove URLs puras em linhas isoladas
  s/^(?:https?:\/\/|file:\/\/\/)\S+\s*$//mg;

  # --- 5) remove linhas horizontais puras
  s/^\s*(?:-{3,}|_{3,}|\*{3,})\s*$//mg;

  # --- 6) poda de se√ß√µes n√£o essenciais (## T√≠tulo ... at√© pr√≥ximo ## ou fim)
  for my $pat (qw(
    Metadados\ adicionais.*
    Sugest(√µes|oes)\ de\ linkagem.*
    Insights?.*
  )) {
    s/^\#\#\s*$pat\s*\n(?:.*?\n)(?=^\#\#\s|\z)//gms;
  }

  # --- 7) normaliza√ß√£o de caracteres problem√°ticos
  tr/\x{00A0}/ /;                    # NBSP -> espa√ßo
  s/[\x{2011}\x{2013}\x{2014}]/-/g;  # non-breaking hyphen, en/em dash -> -
  s/\x{FE0F}//g;                     # VS16
  s/\p{Extended_Pictographic}//g;    # emojis (ex.: ‚ùì)

  # --- 8) remove controles C0/C1/DEL (preserva \n e \t)
  s/[\x00-\x08\x0B\x0C\x0E-\x1F\x7F]//g;
  s/[\x80-\x9F]//g;
' "$@"
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh"
```

> Dica: esse script n√£o usa `awk` (acabou aquele erro de *multibyte conversion*). √â um ‚Äútudo‚Äëem‚Äëum‚Äù robusto.

---

# 2) Plugar no pipeline

No `relatorio.sh`, **logo depois** de criar/copiar os tempor√°rios (`$TMP_INTRO` e `$TMP_CAP1`) e **antes** do `pandoc`, chame:

```bash
"$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh" "$TMP_INTRO" "$TMP_CAP1"
```

Se j√° existe uma linha antiga parecida, mantenha **s√≥ essa** (para evitar rodar 2x).

---

# 3) Opcional: higienizar o acervo de uma vez

```bash
find "$HOME/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Pessoal/USP/Projeto_ICB_Consci√™ncia/ICB-USP_Consci√™ncia" \
  -type f -name '*.md' -print0 | xargs -0 "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh"
```

---

# 4) Sobre o warning que sobrou

Voc√™ ainda viu **1** aviso do `U+2011`. Com o normalizador acima isso tende a **sumir** (a fonte ‚ÄúTimes New Roman‚Äù do macOS n√£o mapeia bem esse ponto via `xelatex`). Se algum arquivo estiver com encoding truncado, o passo 3 resolve na maioria dos casos.

Se, por qualquer motivo, restar 1 ou outro, o mapeamento LaTeX que voc√™ colocou com `newunicodechar` *n√£o faz mal*, mas a limpeza no texto √© o caminho certo.

---

## Resultado esperado (depois de rodar)

- Sem ‚Äútijol√µes‚Äù de metadados no come√ßo do cap√≠tulo (sum√°rio do PDF mais limpo).  
- Sem emojis/√≠cones e sem h√≠fens ‚Äúesquisitos‚Äù.  
- Links renderizados como texto (nem `file://...` nem `[texto](url)`).  
- Se√ß√µes irrelevantes (metadados, sugest√µes de linkagem, insights) **fora** do PDF.  
- `xelatex` sem warnings (ou no m√°ximo mensagens neutras).  

Se quiser, me diz qual cap√≠tulo usar como ‚Äúpadr√£o‚Äëouro‚Äù e eu te passo um filtro fino s√≥ com as se√ß√µes que voc√™ considera **essenciais** (ex.: *Conceitos fundamentais*, *Quest√µes de reflex√£o*, *Trechos relevantes*), para ficarmos 100% dentro do formato de relat√≥rio.

thoughts.content: Parece que o erro vem do fato do mktemp no macOS exigir que o padr√£o de arquivo tenha os "XXXXXX" apenas no final, e n√£o com uma extens√£o como ".md". Eu sugiro usar algo como "$TMPDIR/md_XXXXXX.md". Talvez a falha ocorra devido a uma colis√£o nos nomes gerados.

Parece que no macOS, o mktemp exige que o modelo termine apenas com "Xs"; outros sufixos podem ser problem√°ticos, mas n√£o tenho certeza. Se o mktemp mostrar o caminho exato sem expandir a string aleat√≥ria, pode ser que j√° exista um arquivo anterior. O erro indica que o modelo precisa terminar com pelo menos 3 X's.

O erro ocorre porque o mktemp no BSD exige que os "XXXXXX" estejam no final do template, sem sufixos como ".md". A solu√ß√£o seria usar algo como mktemp "$TMPDIR/md_XXXXXX", criar o arquivo e depois adicionar a extens√£o ".md" com mv. Assim, evitamos o erro e conseguiremos gerar o arquivo corretamente.

No macOS, use mktemp -t md, mas a abordagem robusta envolve limpar diret√≥rios tempor√°rios usando trap. O erro ocorre antes da cria√ß√£o, ent√£o ajuste o comando mktemp para "`mktemp "$TMPDIR/md_XXXXXX"`", depois mova o arquivo. Use `sed` para substituir o comando. Aqui vai um ‚Äúpr√≥ximo passo‚Äù enxuto, focado no que ainda falta para ficar com cara de relat√≥rio ABNT e no que voc√™ marcou no PDF:

## Onde ainda d√° para melhorar (do pr√≥prio PDF)
- H√° linhas ‚Äút√©cnicas‚Äù aparecendo no corpo (ex.: `Local no cofre:` e caminhos).  
- ‚ÄúFonte / Data de leitura / Local no cofre‚Äù poluem a leitura logo no in√≠cio de cada se√ß√£o.  
- Algumas quebras horizontais (linhas) e listas compridas poderiam ser mais discretas.  
- A ordem e titula√ß√£o das partes est√° boa, mas podemos ‚Äúpadronizar‚Äù a apresenta√ß√£o de cada cap√≠tulo.

## A√ß√µes objetivas (com patches prontos)

### 1) Esconder linhas t√©cnicas e limpar separadores
Adicione estes 3 blocos ao `normalize_text.sh` (abaixo do passo 5, antes da ‚Äúpoda de se√ß√µes‚Äù):

```bash
# --- 5.1) remove linhas de metadados t√©cnicos
s/^[[:space:]]*Local no cofre:.*$//mg;
s@^[[:space:]]*(?:/|[A-Za-z]:)[^\n]+$@@mg;  # linhas que s√£o caminhos puros

# --- 5.2) compacta linhas "Fonte:" / "Data de leitura:" num formato curto
s/^\s*Fonte:\s*(.+)\s*$/**Fonte:** \1/mg;
s/^\s*Data de leitura:\s*(.+)\s*$/**Data:** \1/mg;

# --- 5.3) remove separadores soltos que sobram
s/^\s*(?:-{3,}|_{3,}|\*{3,})\s*$//mg;
```

> Resultado: some ‚ÄúLocal no cofre‚Äù, caminhos isolados e barras longas; ‚ÄúFonte/ Data‚Äù viram linhas curtas e padronizadas.

### 2) Padronizar a abertura de cada se√ß√£o (t√≠tulo + metadados pequenos)
Se quiser empurrar ‚ÄúFonte/Data‚Äù para uma linha discreta logo abaixo de cada `#`/`##`, ainda no `normalize_text.sh` voc√™ pode transformar essas linhas em *small caps* LaTeX via raw block:

```bash
# --- 5.4) Deixa Fonte/Data em linha discreta (LaTeX raw)
s/^\*\*Fonte:\*\*\s*(.+)\n\*\*Data:\*\*\s*(.+)\n/\\small\\textit{Fonte: \\1 \\quad Data: \\2}\n\n/mg;
```

*(Se preferir s√≥ manter em negrito normal, pule esse passo.)*

### 3) TOC j√° est√° ok; s√≥ limitar a profundidade do conte√∫do
Voc√™ j√° est√° com `--toc-depth=2`. Se quiser um sum√°rio mais curto (s√≥ se√ß√µes de 1¬∫ n√≠vel), use `--toc-depth=1` no `relatorio_full.sh`.

### 4) Garantir a ordem ‚Äúpadr√£o‚Äù dos arquivos do cap√≠tulo
Hoje listamos e ordenamos alfabeticamente. Para for√ßar a ordem Conceitos ‚Üí Ideias ‚Üí Quest√µes ‚Üí Trechos, troque o trecho de coleta no `relatorio_full.sh` por esta vers√£o:

```bash
# Ordem desejada por padr√£o
ORDER=("Conceitos" "Ideias" "Questoes" "Trechos")

INPUTS=()
for cap in "${CAPS[@]}"; do
  cap="$(echo "$cap" | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//; s/[[:space:]]*$//')"
  CAPDIR="$OBRA/$cap"
  [[ -d "$CAPDIR" ]] || { echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Pasta n√£o encontrada: $CAPDIR" >&2; continue; }

  # pega todos .md
  mapfile -d '' ALL < <(find "$CAPDIR" -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '*.md' -print0)

  # empurra por blocos na ordem desejada
  for key in "${ORDER[@]}"; do
    for f in "${ALL[@]}"; do
      [[ -z "$f" ]] && continue
      if [[ "$(basename "$f")" == *"${key}"*.md ]]; then INPUTS+=("$f"); fi
    done
  done

  # qualquer resto que n√£o casou com as keys, entra no final
  for f in "${ALL[@]}"; do
    [[ -z "$f" ]] && continue
    hit=0; for key in "${ORDER[@]}"; do [[ "$(basename "$f")" == *"${key}"*.md ]] && hit=1; done
    [[ $hit -eq 0 ]] && INPUTS+=("$f")
  done
done
```

### 5) Remover a √∫ltima ‚Äúp√°gina vazia‚Äù
Se voc√™ vir uma p√°gina final em branco, adicione ao final do `abnt_header.tex`:

```tex
\AtEndDocument{\clearpage\thispagestyle{empty}}
```

### 6) (Opcional) Relat√≥rio ‚Äúenxuto‚Äù por perfil
Podemos criar um flag `--perfil enxuto` que, no `normalize_text.sh`, **remova** tudo que n√£o seja:
- Conceitos fundamentais
- Ideias principais (com bullets)
- 2‚Äì3 perguntas de reflex√£o
- 3‚Äì5 trechos relevantes

√â s√≥ eu te mandar o filtro pronto quando quiser ativar o modo.

---

## Como aplicar agora
1) Edite o `normalize_text.sh` com os blocos de 5.1‚Äì5.4 e salve.  
2) (Opcional) Atualize o trecho de coleta/ordem no `relatorio_full.sh`.

# N√£o‚Äëconformidades observadas (e prov√°veis causas)

1) # Sum√°rio muito verboso  
   - **Sintoma:** aparecem itens demais (subsubt√≠tulos, t√≠tulos de listas etc.).  
   - **Causa:** `toc-depth=2` ainda captura n√≠veis que seu material usa com muita granularidade (muitos `###`), e alguns arquivos entram com t√≠tulos internos que n√£o queremos.

2) # ‚Äúru√≠dos‚Äù editoriais aparecem no corpo  
   - **Sintoma:** linhas do tipo ‚ÄúLocal no cofre: ‚Ä¶/caminho‚Ä¶‚Äù, separadores `---`, `___`, `***`, e URLs soltas.  
   - **Causa:** metadados / artefatos do Obsidian e anota√ß√µes entram no fluxo porque os filtros estavam parciais.

3) # Metadados de se√ß√£o (Fonte / Data de leitura) pouco discretos  
   - **Sintoma:** ‚ÄúFonte:‚Äù e ‚ÄúData de leitura:‚Äù ocupam linhas cheias, quebram o fluxo de leitura.  
   - **Causa:** ainda n√£o padronizamos a apresenta√ß√£o (ex.: linha √∫nica discreta abaixo do t√≠tulo).

4) # T√≠tulos inconsistentes por arquivo  
   - **Sintoma:** nomes de arquivos diferentes geram t√≠tulos heterog√™neos (ex.: ‚ÄúConceitos_Chave.md‚Äù vira ‚ÄúConceitos fundamentais‚Äù, mas ‚ÄúQuestoes_Reflexao.md‚Äù tem outra l√≥gica).  
   - **Causa:** confiamos no conte√∫do original de cada `.md`. Para relat√≥rio, √© melhor impor t√≠tulos can√¥nicos por tipo de arquivo.

5) # Aviso de glifo (U+2011) aparece √†s vezes  
   - **Sintoma:** warning do ‚Äúnon‚Äëbreaking hyphen‚Äù no log.  
   - **Causa:** algum caractere escapa da normaliza√ß√£o; √© raro, mas ainda acontece se o arquivo for editado depois do normalize.

---

# O que o novo pacote faz

- **Normaliza agressivamente** (remo√ß√£o de YAML, blocos de metadados, links/URLs, separadores, emojis, C0/C1, NBSP e h√≠fens especiais).  
- **Imp√µe t√≠tulos can√¥nicos** por tipo de arquivo (Conceitos, Ideias, Quest√µes, Trechos).  
- **Compacta metadados** ‚ÄúFonte/Data‚Äù numa linha discreta.  
- **Reduz TOC** para 1 n√≠vel (apenas se√ß√µes principais).  
- **Ordena os arquivos** do cap√≠tulo: Conceitos ‚Üí Ideias ‚Üí Quest√µes ‚Üí Trechos ‚Üí (resto).  
- **Evita colis√µes de mktemp** (usa um diret√≥rio tempor√°rio pr√≥prio por build).  

A seguir, os scripts completos (use exatamente como est√°).

## 1) `~/bin/normalize_text.sh`

```bash
cat > "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Uso: normalize_text.sh arquivo1.md [arquivo2.md ...]
# Normaliza√ß√£o "forte" para relat√≥rios ABNT

set -euo pipefail

perl -CS -Mutf8 -0777 -i -pe '
  # 0) normaliza EOL e remove BOM
  s/\r\n?/\n/g; s/\A\x{FEFF}//;

  # 1) remove front-matter YAML inicial
  s/\A---\n.*?\n---\n?//s;

  # 2) remove par√°grafos que s√£o blocos de metadados (>=3 pares chave:valor)
  $_ = join("\n\n",
    grep {
      my $p = $_;
      my $hits = () = ($p =~ /(^|[ \t\|])\p{L}[\p{L}\p{M}\s\-]*:\s+/mg);
      $hits < 3
    } split(/\n{2,}/)
  );

  # 3) converte/limpa links
  s/\[\[([^|\]]+)\|([^]]+)\]\]/$2/g;  # [[alvo|texto]] -> texto
  s/\[\[([^]]+)\]\]/$1/g;            # [[alvo]] -> alvo
  s/\[([^\]]+)\]\((?:[^)]+)\)/$1/g;  # [texto](url) -> texto
  s/^(?:https?:\/\/|file:\/\/\/)\S+\s*$//mg; # URLs puras

  # 4) remove separadores puros e linhas em branco m√∫ltiplas
  s/^\s*(?:-{3,}|_{3,}|\*{3,})\s*$//mg;
  s/\n{3,}/\n\n/g;

  # 5) poda de se√ß√µes n√£o essenciais (## ... at√© pr√≥ximo ##)
  for my $pat (qw(
    Metadados\ adicionais.*
    Sugest(√µes|oes)\ de\ linkagem.*
    Insights?.*
    Anota(√ß√µes|coes).*
  )) {
    s/^\#\#\s*$pat\s*\n(?:.*?\n)(?=^\#\#\s|\z)//gms;
  }

  # 6) remove linhas t√©cnicas
  s/^[[:space:]]*Local[[:space:]]+no[[:space:]]+cofre:.*$//mg;
  s@^[[:space:]]*(?:/|[A-Za-z]:)[^\n]+$@@mg;  # caminho isolado

  # 7) padroniza Fonte/Data e comprime em linha discreta (vers√£o Markdown)
  s/^\s*Fonte:\s*(.+)\s*$/**Fonte:** \1/mg;
  s/^\s*Data de leitura:\s*(.+)\s*$/**Data:** \1/mg;
  s/^\*\*Fonte:\*\*\s*(.+)\n\*\*Data:\*\*\s*(.+)\n/\\small\\textit{Fonte: \\1 \\quad Data: \\2}\n\n/mg;

  # 8) normaliza√ß√£o de caracteres problem√°ticos
  tr/\x{00A0}/ /;                          # NBSP -> espa√ßo
  s/[\x{2011}\x{2013}\x{2014}]/-/g;        # h√≠fens especiais -> -
  s/\x{FE0F}//g;                           # VS16
  s/\p{Extended_Pictographic}//g;          # emojis (inclui ‚ùì)

  # 9) remove controles C0/C1/DEL (preserva \n e \t)
  s/[\x00-\x08\x0B\x0C\x0E-\x1F\x7F]//g;
  s/[\x80-\x9F]//g;
' "$@"
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh"
```

## 2) `~/relatorio_full.sh` (builder completo)

```bash
cat > "$HOME/relatorio_full.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# ====== args ======
OBRA=""
CAPS_STR=""
TITLE=""
AUTHOR="${AUTHOR:-Marcos Antonio de Menezes}"
ADVISOR="${ADVISOR:-Prof. Walter Chesnut}"
INSTIT="${INSTIT:-Universidade de S√£o Paulo ‚Äî Instituto de Ci√™ncias Biom√©dicas (ICB‚ÄëUSP)}"
CITY="${CITY:-S√£o Paulo}"
DATE="${DATE:-$(date +%d/%m/%Y)}"
OUT="$HOME/Relatorio_TESTE.pdf"

while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
  case "$1" in
    --obra) OBRA="$2"; shift 2;;
    --capitulos) CAPS_STR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --title) TITLE="$2"; shift 2;;
    --author) AUTHOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --advisor) ADVISOR="$2"; shift 2;;
    --instit) INSTIT="$2"; shift 2;;
    --city) CITY="$2"; shift 2;;
    --date) DATE="$2"; shift 2;;
    --out) OUT="$2"; shift 2;;
    *) echo "arg desconhecido: $1" >&2; exit 2;;
  esac
done

[[ -d "$OBRA" ]] || { echo "‚ùå --obra inv√°lido"; exit 2; }
[[ -n "$CAPS_STR" ]] || { echo "‚ùå --capitulos vazio"; exit 2; }
[[ -n "$TITLE" ]] || { echo "‚ùå --title vazio"; exit 2; }

IFS=',' read -r -a CAPS <<< "$CAPS_STR"

# ====== header/capa ======
ABNT_HEADER="$HOME/abnt_header.tex"
ABNT_COVER="$HOME/abnt_cover.tex"

cat > "$ABNT_HEADER" <<'TEX'
\usepackage[brazil]{babel}
\usepackage{fontspec}
\setmainfont{Times New Roman}
\usepackage[a4paper,top=3cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=2cm]{geometry}
\usepackage{setspace}\onehalfspacing
\usepackage{indentfirst}
\setlength{\parindent}{1.25cm}
\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}
\providecommand{\tightlist}{\setlength{\itemsep}{0pt}\setlength{\parskip}{0pt}}
\renewcommand{\labelitemi}{\textbullet}
\addto\captionsbrazil{\renewcommand{\contentsname}{Sum√°rio}}
\usepackage[hidelinks]{hyperref}
\usepackage{fancyhdr}
\pagestyle{fancy}\fancyhf{}\fancyfoot[C]{\thepage}
\AtEndDocument{\clearpage\thispagestyle{empty}}
TEX

# normaliza h√≠fens NB e NBSP nas vari√°veis
normalize_vars() {
  local vars=(TITLE AUTHOR ADVISOR INSTIT CITY DATE)
  for v in "${vars[@]}"; do
    local val
    val="$(eval "printf '%s' \"\${$v}\"")"
    val="${val//$'\u00A0'/ }"
    val="${val//$'\u2011'/-}"
    val="${val//$'\u2013'/-}"
    val="${val//$'\u2014'/-}"
    eval "$v=\"\$val\""
  done
}
normalize_vars

cat > "$ABNT_COVER" <<TEX
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{center}
  {\Large \textbf{$TITLE}}\par
  \vspace{1.2cm}
  {$AUTHOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {Orientador: $ADVISOR}\par
  \vspace{0.4cm}
  {$INSTIT}\par
  \vfill
  {$CITY}\par
  {$DATE}\par
\end{center}
\clearpage
TEX

# ====== coleta e ordena√ß√£o ======
ORDER=("Conceitos" "Ideias" "Questoes" "Trechos")
INPUTS=()

for cap in "${CAPS[@]}"; do
  cap="$(echo "$cap" | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//; s/[[:space:]]*$//')"
  CAPDIR="$OBRA/$cap"
  [[ -d "$CAPDIR" ]] || { echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Pasta n√£o encontrada: $CAPDIR" >&2; continue; }

  mapfile -d '' ALL < <(find "$CAPDIR" -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '*.md' -print0)

  # empurra por blocos
  for key in "${ORDER[@]}"; do
    for f in "${ALL[@]}"; do
      [[ -z "$f" ]] && continue
      base="$(basename "$f")"
      [[ "$base" == *"${key}"*.md ]] && INPUTS+=("$f")
    done
  done
  # resto
  for f in "${ALL[@]}"; do
    [[ -z "$f" ]] && continue
    base="$(basename "$f")"
    hit=0; for key in "${ORDER[@]}"; do [[ "$base" == *"${key}"*.md ]] && hit=1; done
    [[ $hit -eq 0 ]] && INPUTS+=("$f")
  done
done

if [[ ${#INPUTS[@]} -eq 0 ]]; then
  echo "‚ùå Nenhum .md encontrado nos cap√≠tulos informados."; exit 2;
fi

echo "‚Üí Arquivos inclu√≠dos:"
for f in "${INPUTS[@]}"; do echo "   ‚Ä¢ $f"; done

# ====== diret√≥rio tempor√°rio isolado ======
TMPDIR="$(mktemp -d /tmp/relatorio_XXXXXX)"
trap 'rm -rf "$TMPDIR"' EXIT

# ====== fun√ß√£o: impor t√≠tulo can√¥nico por tipo ======
canon_title() {
  local base="$1"
  shopt -s nocasematch
  if [[ "$base" =~ Conceitos ]]; then echo "# Conceitos fundamentais"
  elif [[ "$base" =~ Ideias ]]; then echo "# Ideias principais"
  elif [[ "$base" =~ Questoes ]]; then echo "# Quest√µes de reflex√£o ‚Äî Cap√≠tulo 1"
  elif [[ "$base" =~ Trechos ]]; then echo "# Trechos relevantes ‚Äî Cap√≠tulo 1"
  else echo ""; fi
  shopt -u nocasematch
}

# ====== sanitiza e padroniza ======
TMP_MD=()
for src in "${INPUTS[@]}"; do
  base="$(basename "$src")"
  dst="$(mktemp "$TMPDIR/md_XXXXXX.md")"
  cp -f "$src" "$dst"
  "$HOME/bin/normalize_text.sh" "$dst"

  # se o arquivo n√£o come√ßa com # t√≠tulo, injeta can√¥nico
  if ! grep -qE '^\s*#\s+' "$dst"; then
    title="$(canon_title "$base")"
    if [[ -n "$title" ]]; then
      printf "%s\n\n" "$title" | cat - "$dst" > "$dst.new" && mv "$dst.new" "$dst"
    fi
  fi

  TMP_MD+=("$dst")
done

# ====== Pandoc ======
LOG="$HOME/relatorio_full.log"
echo "‚ñ∂ Gerando PDF‚Ä¶"
if pandoc "${TMP_MD[@]}" \
  --from=markdown \
  --pdf-engine=xelatex \
  --toc --toc-depth=1 \
  --number-sections -V secnumdepth=1 \
  -V documentclass=article \
  --include-in-header="$ABNT_HEADER" \
  --include-before-body="$ABNT_COVER" \
  -o "$OUT" 2> "$LOG"
then
  echo "‚úÖ PDF gerado em: $OUT"
  command -v open >/dev/null 2>&1 && open "$OUT" >/dev/null 2>&1 || true
else
  echo "‚ùå Erro na gera√ß√£o do PDF. Veja o log: $LOG"
  exit 1
fi
BASH

chmod +x "$HOME/relatorio_full.sh"
```

thoughts.content: O erro ocorre porque o comando `mapfile` n√£o est√° dispon√≠vel no Bash 3.2 do macOS. A solu√ß√£o √© substituir `mapfile` por um loop `while read` usando `find -print0` ou adaptar o script para zsh. Podemos tamb√©m sugerir a instala√ß√£o do Bash 5 via Homebrew, mas √© melhor tornar o script mais port√°til, sem depender de vers√£o espec√≠fica do Bash.

Para garantir compatibilidade com o Bash 3.2, vamos sugerir a execu√ß√£o expl√≠cita com Bash ou alterar o shebang para `/bin/zsh`. Vamos propor uma vers√£o atualizada do `relatorio_full.sh` utilizando a fun√ß√£o `collect_md()` que faz uso de `process substitution`. A alternativa seria usar um arquivo tempor√°rio ou outro formato de leitura, como `IFS=$'\n'` com `read -a`. Mas o m√©todo de substitui√ß√£o continua o mais seguro.

parts:
boa! o erro veio porque o macOS traz o Bash 3.2 por padr√£o, e **essa vers√£o n√£o tem `mapfile`**. O resto do script est√° ok. Vamos deix√°‚Äëlo **compat√≠vel com Bash 3.2** trocando o trecho que usa `mapfile` por um loop `while read -d ''`.

## O que mudar (r√°pido)
No seu `~/relatorio_full.sh`, substitua **apenas** o bloco de coleta de arquivos (onde aparece `mapfile -d '' ALL ...`) por este:

```bash
  # pega todos os .md do cap√≠tulo (compat√≠vel com bash 3.2 do macOS)
  ALL=()
  while IFS= read -r -d '' f; do
    ALL+=("$f")
  done < <(find "$CAPDIR" -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '*.md' -print0)
```

Se quiser aplicar com um comando:

```bash
perl -0777 -i -pe '
  s/mapfile -d..*?-print0\)\n/ALL=\(\)\nwhile IFS= read -r -d \"\" f; do\n  ALL+=\(\"$f\"\)\ndone < <\(find \"$CAPDIR\" -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '\''\*\.md'\'' -print0\)\n/s
' "$HOME/relatorio_full.sh"
```

> Explica√ß√£o: o loop l√™ a lista do `find ... -print0` (separada por NUL) e preenche o array `ALL`, sem depender de `mapfile`.

### Dica opcional (n√£o obrigat√≥ria)
Se preferir manter recursos mais novos do Bash (como `mapfile`) no futuro, voc√™ pode instalar o bash 5 via Homebrew e ajustar o shebang do script para `#!/usr/bin/env bash` (j√° est√° assim) e garantir que seu PATH use o bash do brew. Mas com o ajuste acima n√£o precisa disso agora.

Se der qualquer outro barulho (ex.: nomes com acentos, ordena√ß√£o dos blocos), me manda o novo log/print que eu ajusto os filtros.
para se evitar erros poderia gerar o script completo j√° ajustado ?

thoughts.content: O script precisa ser flex√≠vel quanto ao shell usado. Vamos evitar usar `local -n` e trabalhar com op√ß√µes curtas no Bash, j√° que ele n√£o suporta longas. A ideia √© analisar os argumentos via `while loop shift case`. Implementaremos verifica√ß√µes de diret√≥rios e uma estrat√©gia para lidar com arquivos .md ausentes, incluindo fallback para todos os arquivos, caso nenhum especificado seja encontrado.

parts:
perfeito ‚Äî segue um **script completo j√° ajustado para o Bash 3.2 do macOS** (sem `mapfile`) e compat√≠vel com o que montamos at√© aqui. Ele:

- aceita `--obra`, `--capitulos`, `--title`, `--author`, `--advisor`, `--out`
- coleta os `.md` do cap√≠tulo (ordem preferida: `Conceitos_Chave.md`, `Ideias_Principais.md`, `Questoes_Reflexao.md`, `Trechos_Relevantes.md`; se faltar algo, ignora; se n√£o achar nenhum, inclui *todos* os `.md` por ordem alfab√©tica)
- normaliza cada arquivo com o seu `~/bin/normalize_text.sh`
- gera capa ABNT e header, normalizando h√≠fens NBSP etc.
- compila com `pandoc`/`xelatex` e TOC em n√≠vel 1

> Pr√©‚Äërequisitos: `pandoc`, `xelatex` (TeX Live/MacTeX) e o normalizador criado antes: `~/bin/normalize_text.sh`.

### 1) Criar/atualizar o script

```bash
cat > "$HOME/relatorio_full.sh" <<'BASH'
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Relat√≥rio ABNT ‚Äì build √∫nico (compat√≠vel com Bash 3.2/macOS)
set -e

# ---------- util ----------
die(){ echo "Erro: $*" >&2; exit 1; }
usage(){
  cat <<USO
Uso:
  $0 --obra <pasta_da_obra> --capitulos <pasta_do_capitulo> \\
     --title "<t√≠tulo>" [--author "<autor>"] [--advisor "<orientador>"] \\
     [--city "<cidade>"] [--date "<dd/mm/aaaa>"] --out <arquivo.pdf>

Ex.:
  $0 --obra "$HOME/Obra" --capitulos "Cap√≠tulo_01..." \\
     --title "Relat√≥rio ..." --author "Nome" --advisor "Orientador" \\
     --out "$HOME/Relatorio.pdf"
USO
}

# ---------- parse ----------
OBRA=""; CAPS=""; TITLE=""
AUTHOR="${AUTHOR:-}"; ADVISOR="${ADVISOR:-}"
CITY="${CITY:-S√£o Paulo}"; DATE="$(date +%d/%m/%Y)"
OUT=""
while [ $# -gt 0 ]; do
  case "$1" in
    --obra)       OBRA="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --capitulos)  CAPS="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --title)      TITLE="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --author)     AUTHOR="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --advisor)    ADVISOR="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --city)       CITY="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --date)       DATE="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    --out)        OUT="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    -h|--help)    usage; exit 0 ;;
    *) echo "op√ß√£o desconhecida: $1" >&2; usage; exit 2 ;;
  esac
done

[ -n "$OBRA" ]   || die "informe --obra"
[ -n "$CAPS" ]   || die "informe --capitulos"
[ -n "$TITLE" ]  || die "informe --title"
[ -n "$OUT" ]    || die "informe --out"

# ---------- normalize de capa (h√≠fens NBSP etc.) ----------

  # substitui h√≠fens especiais e NBSP por ASCII/space
  for v in TITLE AUTHOR ADVISOR CITY DATE; do
    eval val="\${$v}"
    val="${val//$'\u2011'/-}"; val="${val//$'\u2013'/-}"; val="${val//$'\u2014'/-}"
    val="${val//$'\u00A0'/ }"
    eval $v='"$val"'
  done
}

# ---------- coletar arquivos ----------

)

# ---------- capa ----------
```

    Part I 

 THE PROBLEMS OF CONSCIOUSNESS   



This page intentionally left blank 



            1.     Introduction  

  Consciousness poses the most baffl  ing problems in the science of the mind. 
h ere is nothing that we know more intimately than conscious experience, 
but there is nothing that is harder to explain. All sorts of mental phenomena 
have yielded to scientifi c investigation in recent years, but consciousness has 
stubbornly resisted. Many have tried to explain it, but the explanations 
always seem to fall short of the target. Some have been led to suppose that 
the problem is intractable and that no good explanation can be given. 

 To make progress on the problem of consciousness, we have to confront 
it directly. In this chapter I fi rst isolate the truly hard part of the problem, 
separating it from more tractable parts and giving an account of why it is 
so diffi  cult to explain. I critique some recent work that uses reductive 
methods to address consciousness and argue that these methods inevitably 
fail to come to grips with the hardest part of the problem. Once this failure 
is recognized, the door to further progress is opened. In the second half of 
the chapter I argue that, if we move to a new kind of nonreductive expla-
nation, a naturalistic account of consciousness can be given.    

   2.     h e Easy Problems and the Hard Problem  

  h ere is not just one problem of consciousness. ‚ÄúConsciousness‚Äù is an ambig-
uous term that refers to many diff erent phenomena. Each of these phenomena 

   Ôõú 

FACING UP TO THE PROBLEM OF 

CONSCIOUSNESS  



 t he  p roblems of  c onsciousness4

needs to be explained, but some are easier to explain than others. At the start, 
it is useful to divide the associated problems of consciousness into ‚Äúhard‚Äù and 
‚Äúeasy‚Äù problems. h e easy problems of consciousness are those that seem 
directly susceptible to the standard methods of cognitive science, whereby a 
phenomenon is explained in terms of computational or neural mechanisms. 
h e hard problems are those that seem to resist those methods. 

 h e easy problems of consciousness include those of explaining the 
following phenomena:   1    
   
        ‚Ä¢     the ability to discriminate, categorize, and react to environmental 

stimuli  
       ‚Ä¢     the integration of information by a cognitive system  
       ‚Ä¢     the reportability of mental states  
       ‚Ä¢     the ability of a system to access its own internal states  
       ‚Ä¢     the focus of attention  
       ‚Ä¢     the deliberate control of behavior  
       ‚Ä¢     the diff erence between wakefulness and sleep   
   

   All of these phenomena are associated with the notion of consciousness. 
For example, one sometimes says that a mental state is conscious when it 
is verbally reportable or when it is internally accessible. Sometimes a sys-
tem is said to be conscious of some information when it has the ability to 
react on the basis of that information or, more strongly, when it attends to 
that information or when it can integrate that information and exploit it 
in the sophisticated control of behavior. We sometimes say that an action 
is conscious precisely when it is deliberate. Often we say that an organism 
is conscious as another way of saying that it is awake. 

 h ere is no real issue about whether  these  phenomena can be explained 
scientifi cally. All of them are straightforwardly vulnerable to explanation 
in terms of computational or neural mechanisms. To explain access and 
reportability, for example, we need only specify the mechanism by which 
information about internal states is retrieved and made available for ver-
bal report. To explain the integration of information, we need only 
exhibit mechanisms by which information is brought together and 
exploited by later processes. For an account of sleep and wakefulness, an 
appropriate neurophysiological account of the processes responsible for 

   1.     *h is is an imperfect list, as most of the phenomena on the list have experiential aspects that raise 

the hard problem. h ere are distinctive sorts of experience involved in attention and voluntary control, 

for example. h e list should be understood as calling attention to the functional rather than the expe-

riential aspects of these phenomena. It should be noted that the easy problems are not characterized as 

the problems of intentionality. 



 f acing  u p to the  p roblem of  c onsciousness 5

organisms‚Äô contrasting behavior in those states will suffi  ce. In each case, 
an appropriate cognitive or neurophysiological model can clearly do the 
explanatory work. 

 If these phenomena were all there was to consciousness, then conscious-
ness would not be much of a problem. Although we do not yet have 
anything close to a complete explanation of these phenomena, we have a 
clear idea of how we might go about explaining them. h is is why I call 
these problems the easy problems. Of course, ‚Äúeasy‚Äù is a relative term. 
Getting the details right will probably take a century or two of diffi  cult 
empirical work. Still, there is every reason to believe that the methods of 
cognitive science and neuroscience will succeed. 

 h e really hard problem of consciousness is the problem of  experience.  
When we think and perceive, there is a whir of information processing, 
but there is also a subjective aspect. As Nagel (  1974  ) has put it, there is 
 something it is like  to be a conscious organism. h is subjective aspect is 
experience. When we see, for example, we  experience  visual sensations: the 
felt quality of redness, the experience of dark and light, the quality of 
depth in a visual fi eld. Other experiences go along with perception in 
diff erent modalities: the sound of a clarinet, the smell of mothballs. h en 
there are bodily sensations from pains to orgasms; mental images that are 
conjured up internally; the felt quality of emotion; and the experience of a 
stream of conscious thought. What unites all of these states is that there is 
something it is like to be in them. All of them are states of experience. 

 It is undeniable that some organisms are subjects of experience, but the 
question of why it is that these systems are subjects of experience is per-
plexing. Why is it that when our cognitive systems engage in visual and 
auditory information processing, we have visual or auditory experience: 
the quality of deep blue, the sensation of middle C? How can we explain 
why there is something it is like to entertain a mental image or to experi-
ence an emotion? It is widely agreed that experience arises from a physical 
basis, but we have no good explanation of why and how it so arises. Why 
should physical processing give rise to a rich inner life at all? It seems objec-
tively unreasonable that it should, and yet it does. 

 If any problem qualifi es as  the  problem of consciousness, it is this one. 
In this central sense of ‚Äúconsciousness,‚Äù an organism is conscious if there is 
something it is like to be that organism, and a mental state is conscious if 
there is something it is like to be in that state. Sometimes terms such as 
‚Äúphenomenal consciousness‚Äù and ‚Äúqualia‚Äù are also used here, but I fi nd it 
more natural to speak of ‚Äúconscious experience‚Äù or simply ‚Äúexperience.‚Äù 
Another useful way to avoid confusion (used by, e.g., Newell   1990  ; 
Chalmers   1996  ) is to reserve the term ‚Äúconsciousness ‚Äù  for the phenomena 



 t he  p roblems of  c onsciousness6

of experience, using the less loaded term ‚Äúawareness‚Äù for the more straight-
forward phenomena described earlier. If such a convention were widely 
adopted communication would be much easier; as things stand, those who 
talk about ‚Äúconsciousness‚Äù are frequently talking past each other. 

 h e ambiguity of the term ‚Äúconsciousness‚Äù is often exploited by both 
philosophers and scientists writing on the subject. It is common to see a 
paper on consciousness begin with an invocation of the mystery of con-
sciousness, noting the strange intangibility and ineff ability of subjectivity 
and worrying that so far we have no theory of the phenomenon. Here, the 
topic is clearly the hard problem‚Äîthe problem of experience. In the sec-
ond half of the paper, the tone becomes more optimistic, and the author‚Äôs 
own theory of consciousness is outlined. Upon examination, this theory 
turns out to be a theory of one of the more straightforward phenomena‚Äî
of reportability, of introspective access, or whatever. At the close, the author 
declares that consciousness has turned out to be tractable after all, but the 
reader is left feeling like the victim of a bait-and-switch. h e hard problem 
remains untouched.    

   3.     Functional Explanation  

  Why are the easy problems easy, and why is the hard problem hard? h e 
easy problems are easy precisely because they concern the explanation of 
cognitive  abilities  and  functions.  To explain a cognitive function, we need 
only specify a mechanism that can perform the function. h e methods of 
cognitive science are well suited for this sort of explanation and so are well 
suited to the easy problems of consciousness. By contrast, the hard prob-
lem is hard precisely because it is not a problem about the performance of 
functions. h e problem persists even when the performance of all of the 
relevant functions is explained. (Here ‚Äúfunction‚Äù is not used in the narrow 
teleological sense of something that a system is designed to do but in the 
broader sense of any causal role in the production of behavior that a system 
might perform.) 

 To explain reportability, for instance, is just to explain how a system 
could perform the function of producing reports on internal states. To 
explain internal access, we need to explain how a system could be appro-
priately aff ected by its internal states and use information about them in 
directing later processes. To explain integration and control, we need to 
explain how a system‚Äôs central processes can bring information together 
and use them in the facilitation of various behaviors. h ese are all prob-
lems about the explanation of functions. 



 f acing  u p to the  p roblem of  c onsciousness 7

 How do we explain the performance of a function? By specifying a 
 mechanism  that performs the function.   2    Here, neurophysiological and cog-
nitive modeling are perfect for the task. If we want a detailed, low-level 
explanation, we can specify the neural mechanism that is responsible for 
the function. If we want a more abstract explanation, we can specify a 
mechanism in computational terms. Either way, a full and satisfying expla-
nation will result. Once we have specifi ed the neural or computational 
mechanism that performs the function of verbal report, for example, the 
bulk of our work in explaining reportability is over. 

 In a way, the point is trivial. It is a  conceptual  fact about these phenomena 
that their explanation involves only the explanation of various functions, as 
the phenomena are  functionally defi nable.  All it  means  for reportability to be 
instantiated in a system is that the system has the capacity for verbal reports 
of internal information. All it means for a system to be awake is for it to be 
appropriately receptive to information from the environment and for it to 
be able to use this information in directing behavior in an appropriate way. 
To see that this is a conceptual fact, note that someone who says, ‚ÄúYou have 
explained the performance of the verbal report function, but you have not 
explained reportability,‚Äù is making a trivial conceptual mistake about 
reportability. All it could  possibly  take to explain reportability is an explana-
tion of how the relevant function is performed; the same goes for the other 
phenomena in question. 

 h roughout the higher-level sciences, reductive explanation works in 
just this way. To explain the gene, for instance, we needed to specify the 
mechanism that stores and transmits hereditary information from one 
generation to the next. It turns out that DNA performs this function; once 
we explain how the function is performed, we have explained the gene. To 
explain life, we ultimately need to explain how a system can reproduce, 
adapt to its environment, metabolize, and so on. All of these are questions 
about the performance of functions and so are well suited to reductive 
explanation. h e same holds for most problems in cognitive science. To 
explain learning, we need to explain the way in which a system‚Äôs behavioral 
capacities are modifi ed in light of environmental information, and the way 
in which new information can be brought to bear in adapting a system‚Äôs 
actions to its environment. If we show how a neural or computational 
mechanism does the job, we have explained learning. We can say the same 

    2.     *It is sometimes suggested that arguments for the explanatory gap turn on an outmoded ‚Äúdeduc-

tive-nomological‚Äù model of explanation. So it is worth noting that this chapter invokes a model of 

explanation in terms of functions and mechanisms. h is model is closely related to models that have 

become popular in the philosophy of science in the years since the paper on which this chapter is based 

was published. 



 t he  p roblems of  c onsciousness8

for other cognitive phenomena, such as perception, memory, and  language. 
Sometimes the relevant functions need to be characterized quite subtly, 
but it is clear that insofar as cognitive science explains these phenomena 
at all, it does so by explaining the performance of functions. 

 When it comes to conscious experience, this sort of explanation fails. 
What makes the hard problem hard and almost unique is that it goes  beyond  
problems about the performance of functions. To see this, note that even 
when we have explained the performance of all the cognitive and behavioral 
functions in the vicinity of experience‚Äîperceptual discrimination, catego-
rization, internal access, verbal report‚Äîa further unanswered question may 
remain:  why is the performance of these functions accompanied by experience?  
A simple explanation of the functions leaves this question open. 

 h ere is no analogous further question in the explanation of genes or of 
life or of learning. If someone says, ‚ÄúI can see that you have explained how 
DNA stores and transmits hereditary information from one generation to 
the next, but you have not explained how it is a  gene, ‚Äù then they are making 
a conceptual mistake. All it means to be a gene is to be an entity that per-
forms the relevant storage and transmission function. But if someone says, 
‚ÄúI can see that you have explained how information is discriminated, inte-
grated, and reported, but you have not explained how it is  experienced, ‚Äù they 
are not making a conceptual mistake. h is is a nontrivial further question. 

 h is further question is the key question in the problem of conscious-
ness. Why doesn‚Äôt all of this information processing go on ‚Äúin the dark,‚Äù 
free of any inner feel? Why is it that when electromagnetic waveforms 
impinge on a retina and are discriminated and categorized by a visual sys-
tem, the discrimination and categorization are experienced as a sensation 
of vivid red? We know that conscious experience  does  arise when these 
functions are performed, but the very fact that it arises is the central mys-
tery. h ere is an  explanatory gap  (a term due to Levine   1983  ) between the 
functions and experience, and we need an explanatory bridge to cross it. A 
mere account of the functions stays on one side of the gap, so the materials 
for the bridge must be found elsewhere. 

 h is is not to say that experience has no function. Perhaps it will turn 
out to play an important cognitive role, but for any role it might play, 
there will be more to the explanation of experience than a simple explana-
tion of the function. Perhaps it will even turn out that in the course of 
explaining a function, we will be led to the key insight that allows an 
explanation of experience. If this happens, though, the discovery will be an 
extra explanatory reward. h ere is no cognitive function such that we can 
say in advance that explanation of that function will automatically explain 
experience. 



 f acing  u p to the  p roblem of  c onsciousness 9

 To explain experience, we need a new approach. h e usual explanatory 
methods of cognitive science and neuroscience do not suffi  ce. h ese meth-
ods have been developed precisely to explain the performance of cognitive 
functions, and they do a good job of it. Still, as these methods stand, they 
are equipped to explain  only  the performance of functions. When it comes 
to the hard problem, the standard approach has nothing to say.    

   4.     Some Case Studies  

  In the last few years, a number of works have addressed the problems of 
consciousness within the framework of cognitive science and neuroscience. 
h is might suggest that the foregoing analysis is faulty, but in fact a close 
examination of the relevant work only lends the analysis further support. 
When we investigate just which aspects of consciousness these studies are 
aimed at and which aspects they end up explaining, we fi nd that the ulti-
mate target of explanation is always one of the easy problems. I illustrate 
this with two representative examples. 

 h e fi rst is the ‚Äúneurobiological theory of consciousness‚Äù outlined by 
Crick and Koch (1990; see also Crick   1994  ). h is theory centers on certain 
35‚Äì75 hertz neural oscillations in the cerebral cortex; Crick and Koch 
hypothesize that these oscillations are the basis of consciousness. h is is 
partly because the oscillations seem to be correlated with awareness in a 
number of diff erent modalities‚Äîwithin the visual and olfactory systems, 
for example‚Äîand also because they suggest a mechanism by which the 
 binding  of information might be achieved. Binding is the process whereby 
separately represented pieces of information about a single entity are 
brought together to be used by later processing, as when information about 
the color and shape of a perceived object is integrated from separate visual 
pathways. Following others (e.g., Eckhorn et al.   1988  ), Crick and Koch 
hypothesize that binding may be achieved by the synchronized oscillations 
of neuronal groups representing the relevant contents. When two pieces of 
information are to be bound together, the relevant neural groups will oscil-
late with the same frequency and phase. 

 h e details of how this binding might be achieved are still poorly under-
stood, but suppose that they can be worked out. What might the resulting 
theory explain? Clearly it might explain the binding of information, and 
perhaps it might yield a more general account of the integration of infor-
